page.title: 15Heather through the Years
page.content: Heather village was very different in the old days. About 1910 it had two bakers, two butchers, a tailor, shoe repairer, blacksmith, shoeing smithy and even a bank; but all these, together with three thatched cottages and seventy original houses, have now gone. Local emplyment was mostly in farming or mining, but also brick making, building and, later, motor engineering and haulage firms. The railway transported coal, bricks and stone as well as passengers. The stone was taken from the trucks, put into carts which were pulled by horses and dumped by the roadside. The roadmender would fetch some in his barrow, shovel it into the hole in the road and bang it in - and that was that! Sometimes the farmers would send corn, potatoes and milk by train.
